Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 9d7cf2fbcbc1a645d80e3a6472d546c022061ccb

The reason for changing the status to WIP：
EE hope to add a filter function to ensure that the BMC will not confirm whether an interrupt occurs when the blade is hot-plugged.

Can we use something more descript than these seemingly random numbers?  I understand these are probably GPIO pin numbers or something, but why not use a human understandable parameter at the injection point?
I will change the input parameters from numbers 14/58 to strings slot1-slot4/slot5-slot8 to make it understandable.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
We should not be forcing states in PSM directly.  Please use state transitions to ensure we run all the appropriate code.

Please let us explain why we would modify CurrentHostState directly：
- When the CPU power status changes when the BMC is aware of it (for example: the user uses mfg-tool for power control): The mfg-tool command will perform the power-control behavior that should be performed.
- The CPU power status changes without the BMC knowing it (for example: a power fault occurs causing cpu power off): Since the CPU has been powered off, we have to change the CPU power state to off.

Based on the current situation: 
  - If RequestedHostTransition is controlled to off after a CPU power off occurs：
    The executed host-poweroff script will print out the log of "Already host power off".
    
Would you hope that we can use RequestedHostTransition to ensure that the code that needs to be executed can be executed?

Reference log：
[]
Sep 09 01:22:31 bmc mfg-tool[6931]: Attempting runtime:off on 6.

I changed it to RequestedHostTransition to confirm that the execution part has been executed.
I'm not very happy about how many raw i2ctransfers we are ending up with here.  I thought we had a driver for this chip.  Why do we keep having to go around the driver?

Sorry.
I will use gpioget to confirm whether the setting value is successful.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.

Why doesn't this use a %i?

Is there a reason why we have to order like this?  Is there really any case where these services aren't running by the time this interrupt fires?  Is there any reason we can't handle it in the code itself?

This part is just to confirm that the service is running when the interrupt occurs.
According to the previously mentioned input parameters, it will be changed to the string slot1-slot4/slot5-slot8, so we can only directly list the services that need to be executed here instead of using %i.
Under normal circumstances, this interrupt will be performed after the service is running.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
Why do you need these then if you're doing a mapper-wait?
I will remove this part.
Done. Please help to review, thank you.

Hi Patrick：
We add a 10ms delay based on EE's recommendations to confirm whether the interrupt pin is actually triggered.
Code has been modified according to suggestions, please help to review.
Hi Patrick：Because this modification will fix the critical issue, please help me review it, thank you.

Hi Patrick：Please help to review this commit, thank you.
